name: Mozambique
currentCrisisSummary:
Mozambique confronts a violent insurgency in its northern Cabo Delgado province, a conflict directly driven by the **'resource curse'** and **decades of state neglect rooted in colonial underdevelopment**. The discovery of massive natural gas reserves attracted billions in foreign investment but brought **no benefit to the local population**, instead fuelling **displacement, dispossession, and deep-seated grievances**.

This fertile ground for rebellion is exploited by an insurgency the **corrupt, centralised state** cannot contain. The conflict is internationalised, involving regional troops and private mercenaries hired to protect **multi-billion dollar gas projects**. It exemplifies a crisis born from a **predatory economic model**: state collaboration with multinational corporations to extract wealth, treating citizens as obstacles and **structurally producing the conditions for violent uprising and widespread suffering**.

colonialRoot.legacy:
Portugal's colonial rule in Mozambique was one of the most brutal and underdeveloped in Africa. The economy was built on a system of forced labour (chibalo) for plantations and mines, land was expropriated for Portuguese settlers, and there was virtually no investment in education or healthcare for the African majority. The colonial state was purely an instrument of extraction and violent control.

This legacy meant that at independence, Mozambique was left impoverished, with no skilled administrators, and a society deeply scarred by systemic violence. The long and bloody war of liberation against Portugal, led by FRELIMO, further entrenched a militarised political culture. This was compounded by a final, deliberate act of economic sabotage. As over 200,000 Portuguese settlers fled between 1974-1975, they engaged in a scorched-earth withdrawal: taking their capital, destroying industrial and farm machinery, and slaughtering livestock. This campaign was designed to cripple the new state from its inception, ensuring independence began in a state of near-total economic collapse.

historicalContext.title: Post-Independence Destabilisation
historicalContext.description: After FRELIMO led Mozambique to independence in 1975 and established a socialist state, it was immediately targeted by the white-minority regimes of Rhodesia and apartheid South Africa. These regimes created, funded, and directed the RENAMO insurgency, plunging the country into a devastating 16-year civil war. This was a deliberate, externally-driven campaign of destabilisation to destroy an alternative, anti-racist political project in the region. The war shattered the country's infrastructure and caused immense human suffering.

historicalContext.title: Neoliberal Debt and Structural Adjustment
historicalContext.description: Devastated by the war, Mozambique was forced to turn to the IMF and World Bank in the late 1980s. The subsequent Structural Adjustment Programmes mandated a rapid shift to a market economy through mass privatisation of state industries and severe cuts to public services. While enriching a small FRELIMO-connected elite and opening the country to foreign capital, these neoliberal reforms entrenched inequality and failed to alleviate the deep-seated poverty that fuels instability.

historicalContext.title: The Resource Curse and Elite Corruption
historicalContext.description: The discovery of massive gas reserves in Cabo Delgado and the ongoing illicit trade in resources like rubies and timber have supercharged corruption. This is exemplified by the '$2 Billion Hidden Debts' scandal, where state elites and international banks (notably Credit Suisse) colluded in a massive loan fraud, ostensibly for maritime security, which was largely embezzled. This act of grand corruption crippled the national budget, deepened dependency, and confirmed to many citizens that the state exists primarily to enrich a politically connected elite and their foreign partners.

historicalContext.title: International Law And Accountability
historicalContext.description: Accountability for both historic and contemporary crimes remains elusive. While the 'hidden debts' scandal has led to legal proceedings in multiple countries, the key political figures in Mozambique have largely escaped consequences. In Cabo Delgado, there are credible reports of serious human rights abuses by the insurgents, state security forces, and foreign private military contractors. However, there is no effective mechanism for investigating these crimes or providing justice for victims, creating a cycle of impunity.

humanitarianImpact.title: Displacement
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 784,000 people internally displaced, forcibly uprooted by the **violence stemming from the gas insurgency and state counter-insurgency.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Refugees
humanitarianImpact.description: Thousands forced into precarious asylum in Tanzania by the **conflict dynamics**, though most displacement remains internal.

humanitarianImpact.title: Casualties
humanitarianImpact.description: Thousands of civilians killed since 2017, victims of the **brutal conflict driven by resource wealth and historical neglect.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Affected Population
humanitarianImpact.description: An estimated 1.5 million people require urgent aid due to the **breakdown of society and services caused by the resource-fuelled war.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Food Insecurity
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 900,000 face acute hunger as the **conflict disrupts agriculture and access in historically marginalised northern regions.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Healthcare Collapse
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 100 health facilities destroyed, leaving populations vulnerable due to **direct attacks and the state's failure to protect infrastructure.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Education Disrupted
humanitarianImpact.description: Hundreds of thousands of children denied education as schools are destroyed or closed by **insecurity linked to the gas conflict.**

timeline.event: **Formal Colonisation**: In the 'Scramble for Africa', Portugal leases vast territories to private charter companies to enforce its colonial claim. These companies impose brutal rule, seizing land and instituting the 'chibalo' system of forced labour to plunder resources.

**Formation of FRELIMO**: Uniting several nationalist groups, the Mozambique Liberation Front (FRELIMO) is founded in exile under the leadership of Eduardo Mondlane, with the explicit goal of launching an armed struggle against Portuguese rule.
**War of Independence**: The FRELIMO liberation front wages a decade-long armed struggle against Portuguese colonial rule.

**Scorched-Earth Exodus**: Following a coup in Portugal, departing settlers engage in widespread economic sabotage, destroying infrastructure and assets to deliberately cripple the economy of the soon-to-be independent nation.
**Independence**: Mozambique becomes independent, with FRELIMO forming a single-party socialist state.
**Civil War of Destabilisation**: The apartheid-backed RENAMO insurgency wages a brutal proxy war against the FRELIMO government, leading to the deaths of around one million people.
**Neoliberal Turn**: Under immense pressure, FRELIMO abandons Marxism-Leninism and accepts a new constitution and IMF-led structural adjustment, opening the economy to foreign capital.
**Gas Discovery**: Enormous offshore natural gas reserves are discovered in the Rovuma Basin off the coast of Cabo Delgado, sparking a rush for concessions by multinational energy firms.
**'Hidden Debts' Scandal**: A $2 billion loan and corruption scandal involving state elites and international banks is exposed, triggering a financial crisis.

**Cabo Delgado Insurgency**: A violent insurgency rooted in local grievances over poverty and resource extraction begins in Cabo Delgado, attacking state and civilian targets and displacing hundreds of thousands.

donate.description: A leading Mozambican civil society organisation that promotes transparency, good governance, and fights corruption, particularly in the extractive industries.
UNHCR provides life-saving protection, shelter, and emergency supplies to hundreds of thousands of people displaced by the conflict and climate shocks in Mozambique.

advocacy: Demand the full cancellation of Mozambique's odious debts, including those from the 'hidden debts' scandal, to free up public funds for essential services.
Advocate for transparency and accountability in the natural resource sector, ensuring that gas revenues benefit the entire population, especially local communities.
Support calls for an end to impunity for human rights abuses committed by all parties to the conflict in Cabo Delgado.
Promote community-led development models that give local populations meaningful control over their land and resources.
Call for the prosecution of the international banks and financial actors who facilitated the corrupt 'hidden debts' scandal.

reading.title: A Complicated War: The Harrowing of Mozambique
reading.description: William Finnegan's profound account of the devastating civil war fueled by apartheid South Africa and its impact on civilians.

reading.title: The Wretched of the Earth
reading.description: Frantz Fanon's foundational text on colonialism, violence, and liberation, essential for understanding Mozambique's anti-colonial struggle.
